messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Ramanujan Graphs and Interlacing Families

Paper Abstract: Abstract This survey accompanies a lecture on the paper “Interlacing Families I: Bipartite Ramanujan Graphs of All Degrees” [40] by A. Marcus, D. Spielman, and N. Srivastava which was awarded a Frontiers of Science Award at the 2024 ICBS in July, 2024. Its purpose is to explain the developments surrounding this work over the past ten or so years, with an emphasis on connections to other areas of mathematics. Earlier surveys about the interlacing families method by the same authors [39, 37] focused on applications in functional analysis, whereas the focus here is on applications in spectral graph theory.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The monotone circuit complexity of boolean functions",
        "Stable multivariate generalizations of matching polynomials",
        "The kadison-singer problem for strongly rayleigh measures and applications to asymmetric tsp",
        "Approximating the largest root and applications to interlacing families",
        "ss-transform in finite free probability",
        "Finite free cumulants: multiplicative convolutions, genus expansion and infinitesimal distributions",
        "Cumulants for finite free convolution",
        "Edge rigidity and universality of random regular graphs of intermediate degree",
        "Lifts, discrepancy and nearly optimal spectral gap",
        "The lee-yang and pólya-schur programs. i. linear operators preserving stability",
        "The lee-yang and pólya-schur programs. ii. theory of stable polynomials and applications",
        "A new proof of friedman’s second eigenvalue theorem and its extension to random lifts",
        "Eigenvalues of random lifts and polynomials of random permutation matrices",
        "On akemann-weaver conjecture",
        "A new approach to strong convergence",
        "Ramanujan graphs and shimura curves",
        "Ramanujan graphs in polynomial time",
        "Random matrices, magic squares and matching polynomials",
        "On the eigenvalues of random matrices",
        "Some geometric aspects of graphs and their eigenfunctions",
        "Relative expanders or weakly relatively ramanujan graphs",
        "A proof of Alon’s second eigenvalue conjecture and related problems",
        "On the relativized alon second eigenvalue conjecture i: Main theorems, examples, and outline of proof",
        "On the matching polynomial of a graph",
        "Crystallization of random matrix orbits",
        "On the spectrum of graphs and their universal covering",
        "A theory of singular values for finite free probability",
        "Ramanujan coverings of graphs",
        "Theory of monomer-dimer systems",
        "Near optimal spectral gaps for hyperbolic surfaces",
        "Optimal eigenvalue rigidity of random regular graphs",
        "Edge universality of sparse random matrices",
        "Random matrix theory and ζ\\zeta (1/2+ it)",
        "Discrete groups, expanding graphs and invariant measures, volume 125",
        "Not every uniform tree covers ramanujan graphs",
        "Ramanujan graphs",
        "The solution of the kadison-singer problem",
        "Polynomial convolutions and (finite) free probability",
        "Ramanujan graphs and the solution of the kadison-singer problem",
        "Interlacing families i: Bipartite ramanujan graphs of all degrees",
        "Interlacing families ii: Mixed characteristic polynomials and the kadison—singer problem",
        "Interlacing families iv: Bipartite ramanujan graphs of all sizes",
        "Finite free convolutions of polynomials",
        "Explicit group-theoretical constructions of combinatorial schemes and their application to the design of expanders and concentrators",
        "The expected eigenvalue distribution of a large regular graph",
        "The distribution of the largest nontrivial eigenvalues in families of random regular graphs",
        "xx-ramanujan graphs",
        "Expansion of random graphs: New proofs, new results",
        "Mixed determinants and the kadison–singer problem",
        "Heaps of pieces, i: Basic definitions and combinatorial lemmas",
        "Limit laws for random matrices and free products",
        "On the location of the roots of certain types of polynomials",
        "Models of random regular graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Ramanujan Graphs and Interlacing Families, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
